support_summary: VCP extracts the sterically trapped Ku70/80 (XRCC6/XRCC5) ring-shaped complex from DNA after the completion of double-strand break repair.

functions.cellular_process: Following the completion of DNA double-strand break repair by Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ), the Ku70/80 (XRCC6/XRCC5) heterodimer remains topologically entrapped on the DNA molecule. The VCP/p97 ATPase, in complex with its ubiquitin-adapter cofactors Ufd1-Npl4, is recruited to the site. VCP specifically targets K48-linked polyubiquitin chains on the Ku80 subunit (XRCC5). Utilizing the energy from ATP hydrolysis, VCP then extracts the entire ring-shaped Ku70/80 heterodimer from the DNA, clearing the repair site and terminating the process.
functions.effect_description: Mediates the final step of NHEJ by using its ATPase activity to extract the sterically trapped Ku70/80 (XRCC6/XRCC5) complex from DNA, which is essential for clearing the chromatin and completing the repair process.
biological_consequence: Completion of NHEJ → Ku70/80 heterodimer is sterically trapped on DNA → Ku80 (XRCC5) is modified with K48-linked polyubiquitin chains → The VCP-Ufd1-Npl4 complex is recruited to ubiquitinated Ku80 → VCP's ATPase activity remodels and extracts the Ku70/80 ring from DNA → DNA repair site is cleared for downstream processes
specific_effects: VCP requires its ATPase activity and the Ufd1-Npl4 ubiquitin-adapter complex to release DNA-locked Ku rings.
VCP-mediated removal of Ku70/80 is critical for preventing the persistence of repair factors on chromatin, which can be genotoxic.
The extraction process is dependent on the K48-linked ubiquitination of the XRCC5 (Ku80) subunit.

evidence.paper_title: VCP/p97 Extracts Sterically Trapped Ku70/80 Rings from DNA in Double-Strand Break Repair
evidence.relevant_quote: During DNA double-strand break (DSB) repair, the ring-shaped Ku70/80 complex becomes trapped on DNA and needs to be actively extracted... we demonstrate here that DNA-locked Ku rings are released by the AAA-ATPase p97. To achieve this, p97 requires ATP hydrolysis, cooperates with the Ufd1-Npl4 ubiquitin-adaptor complex, and specifically targets Ku80 that is modified by K48-linked ubiquitin chains.
